Simon Chappell wrote:
> On 5/22/05, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
> *snip*
>  > But aside from a few
>  > weird cases like that, all code should be tested or deleted.
> 
> I'm with you on this one. Just don't let JB catch you saying that! :-)

I don't mind it. I don't even mind Elliotte disagreeing with me in, say, 
one of his articles. :) He obviously feels the ROI for testing really 
simple code (get/set) to be higher than I do. Until we can measure that 
somewhat objectively, neither one of us can say more than "I don't agree 
with him". As long as we agree not to say, "He's wrong; what an idiot!" 
then I'll be very happy. So far, he doesn't appear to have called me 
wrong or an idiot, and I certainly haven't done that to him.

I'm intrigued by extreme heuristics like "all code should be either 
tested or deleted". I suppose I should try that on a project and see 
what happens. Maybe I'll be pleasantly surprised.
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
